awd_titl_txt: EFRI ACQUIRE: Development of scalable quantum networks using ion chips and integrated photonics
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract title: EFRI ACQUIRE: Development of scalable quantum networks using ion chips and integrated photonics

Abstract:

Nontechnical description: Utilizing quantum mechanical systems to transmit and process information provides a fundamental advantage over classical approaches, with foundational impact on the fields of communication, networking, computer science, and fundamental quantum physics. A seminal example is the quantum network. In contrast to a classical communication networks, a quantum network stores and transmits information using quantum objects such as single atoms and single photons. By doing so, a quantum network can communicate with unconditional security and anonymity, and can also interconnect quantum computers to form a quantum internet. But realizing these technological capabilities requires the ability to store and transmit quantum information while preserving the delicate quantum state of the system. Ions trapped in electric fields constitute the best quantum memory to date. They can store quantum information for times exceeding tens of minutes, and can also emit single photons, the ideal carriers of quantum information that are entangled with quantum memory. But a number of significant challenges remain before a trapped-ion quantum network can become a reality. Ions emit visible- and ultraviolet-wavelength photons that are not compatible with fiber-optic networks. These photons must also be processed with high efficiency without destroying the delicate quantum signals that they carry.  In this program, we will combine silicon-chip traps and integrated photonics to overcome these challenges.  If successful, this project will provide the core hardware for a scalable and efficient quantum network that can process and transmit quantum information with unprecedented speed and distance.

Technical abstract: By combining integrated photonics with silicon-based ion-chip traps, we will develop the technology for scalable quantum networks based on compact, chip-integrated quantum hardware operating at room temperature. Trapped ions are currently the leading platform for quantum information processing, with coherence times exceeding tens of minutes. They are also one of the few room-temperature sources of indistinguishable single photons that can exhibit the two-photon interference effects required for photon-mediated quantum interactions. The program will utilize micro-fabricated ion-chip traps to assemble and manipulate atomic ion chains on a silicon chip that serve as both efficient room-temperature single-photon sources and long-lived quantum memories. Integrated photonic structures will process photons originating from multiple ion traps to mediate long-distance quantum interactions at unprecedented efficiencies and fidelities. Integrated nonlinear photonic devices will furthermore convert photons emitted by trapped ions to telecom wavelengths for long-distance fiber propagation. The project will deploy and demonstrate compact quantum devices in a practical optical network. This highly multi-disciplinary program ultimately aims to demonstrate the fundamental operations of a quantum network, which can be used for entanglement distribution, quantum error correction, and distribution of quantum information and quantum keys.

por.por_cntn:
Utilizing quantum resources to transmit and process information provides a fundamental advantage over classical approaches, with foundational impact on the fields of communication, networking, computer science, and fundamental quantum physics. This proposal aimed to develop the technology for scalable quantum networks based on compact chip-integrated quantum hardware operating at room temperature by combining silicon-based ion chip traps with integrated photonics. Trapped ions are currently the leading platform for quantum information processing, with coherence times exceeding tens of minutes.  They are also one of the few room-temperature sources of indistinguishable single photons that can exhibit the two-photon interference effects required for photon-mediated quantum interactions.  We used micro-fabricated ion-chip traps to assemble and manipulate atomic ion chains on a silicon chip that serve as both efficient room-temperature single-photon sources and long-lived quantum memories. We developed integrated photonic devices that route photons originating from multiple ion traps to mediate long-distance quantum interactions at unprecedented efficiencies and fidelities. We also developed integrated nonlinear photonic devices that convert photons emitted by trapped ions to telecom wavelengths for long-distance fiber propagation. The project deployed and demonstrated compact quantum devices in a practical optical network.  This highly multi-disciplinary program ultimately lays the foundations to demonstrate the fundamental operations of a quantum network, which can be used for entanglement distribution, quantum error correction, and distribution of quantum information and quantum keys.

Intellectual Merits: This project combined trapped-ion technology with integrated photonics devices, a highly unexplored area of research that leverages the respective strengths of these two systems to attain a scalable quantum network. The successful integration of these two fields could open up a new area of research where fast, integrated photonic devices mediate interactions between stable, chip-integrated quantum memory elements. The program also developed compact quantum hardware capable of storing and distributing quantum information at unprecedented capacities, laying the path for remarkable applications such as secure and anonymous quantum networks, distributed quantum information processors, precision global clocks, and coherent imaging based on quantum telescopes.  This highly multi-disciplinary effort addressed some of the most pressing device-level engineering issues that represent leading road-blocks for distributed, scalable quantum technology. Access to highly complex quantum systems will enhance the fundamental scientific understanding of quantum physics, entanglement, decoherence, and quantum-to-classical correspondence by enabling a thorough study of quantum systems of significant complexity.            

Broader Impact: Just as the internet has opened up the door to the information age, quantum networks will have foundational impact on society by providing new communication paradigms for quantum resources.  Scalable quantum information processing is regarded as one of the fundamental grand-challenges of quantum physics. Currently, very little is known about the behavior of complex distributed quantum systems since they cannot be efficiently simulated on a classical computer. Quantum information will shed new light on this unexplored and inaccessible regime of physics and significantly enhance our fundamental understanding of quantum physics. This proposal aimed to address the fundamental scalability issues that will enable us to harness this vast resource.
